title: Sichuan Dry-Fried Green Beans
description: Crisp-tender green beans blistered in hot oil and tossed with aromatic Sichuan ingredients for a smoky, savory, and slightly numbing finish. Garlic, ginger, fermented chili bean paste, and a touch of sugar create a complex balance of heat, umami and brightness using a quick wok-fry technique.

ingredients.display_name: fresh green beans, trimmed and halved if long
ingredients.notes: trim ends; leave whole or cut in half for larger beans

ingredients.display_name: neutral oil (vegetable or peanut) for frying
ingredients.notes: enough for shallow-deep frying to blister beans
adjust for heat; use less for milder
added near end to avoid burning

ingredients.display_name: dried red chili flakes or whole dried chilies (optional extra heat)
ingredients.notes: use crushed whole dried chilies for more aromatic heat

ingredients.display_name: scallions, thinly sliced (white and green parts separated)
ingredients.notes: white part added when frying aromatics, green used as garnish
adds numbing floral note; use sparingly

steps.text: Prepare beans by trimming ends and, if very long, cutting them in half; pat dry thoroughly to prevent oil splatter.
Heat a wok or large heavy skillet over high heat until smoking hot, then add the neutral oil and swirl to coat. Allow oil to come to temperature (shimmering).

Add the green beans in a single layer and fry, stirring or shaking the pan frequently so beans blister evenly and develop charred spots; continue until they are blistered and mostly tender but still bright green.
Using a slotted spoon, remove most of the oil leaving about 1 tablespoon in the wok; reserve excess oil if desired. Reduce heat to medium-high.
Add the white parts of scallions, ginger, optional dried chilies and toasted sichuan peppercorns to the remaining oil and stir-fry briefly until aromatic (about 20–30 seconds) without burning.
Stir in the doubanjiang and fry it for 30–45 seconds to bloom the paste, then add minced garlic and cook for another 15–20 seconds until fragrant.

Return blistered green beans to the wok; add light soy sauce, rice vinegar, sugar and salt. Toss vigorously so sauce coats the beans evenly; cook until sauce reduces and clings to beans, about 1–2 minutes.
Finish by drizzling toasted sesame oil, adding sliced green parts of scallions, and tossing once more. Taste and adjust seasoning, then remove from heat.
Transfer to a serving plate and serve hot as a side or part of a larger meal; leftovers keep refrigerated for 2–3 days.
